text: research is telling us more and more
about what tools people diagnosed with
ADHD can use to help them be their most
productive selves but the good news is
that anyone looking to improve their
focus can use them to their advantage to
get their work done in this video we'll
explore four science back techniques and
strategies for boosting concentration
let's get into it tip number one is to
try body doubling have you ever wondered
why often times it's easier to focus in
a public place like an office or Library
when surrounded by people also trying to
concentrate well you're not alone
research shows that being in the
presence of others even if they're
strangers can help us get our work done
this is the inspiration behind a
technique known as body doubling the
ADHD Community has known about body
doubling for a while but it's recently
become popular with anyone looking to
boost their productivity to practice
body doubling find someone a friend
family member or colleague to be your
accountability partner ideally they'd be
someone working on a task similar to
yours but they don't have to be as long
as they don't distract you from your
work often just being there is enough
for example you could try writing a
school paper while your body double does
their laundry in the same room you can
also body double in a group and it works
just as well virtually using video call
software you can even use strangers in a
coffee shop without them ever knowing
body doubles are passive they don't
actively tell you to stay on task but
simply act as a reminder that there's
something you're meant to be working on
you might wonder whether the technique
has much impact but you'd be surprised
even this subtle form of accountability
makes you much less likely to spend time
mindlessly scrolling on social media or
rearranging your backpack for the third
time when you should be studying
subconsciously we're much better behaved
when we think someone might be watching
and judging us most of us would be
embarrassed to go to the library and
spend all day procrastinating even if
only in front of strangers research on
why body doubling is effective is only
beginning but scientists have proposed
several explanations one theory is that
people with ADHD have low level of
dopamine a chemical in the brain related
to pleasure and reward which makes it
harder for them to focus body doubling
might work because study show that
social interactions can increase
dopamine levels another explanation is
simply that body doubling works because
of the audience effect an effect
discovered over a hundred years ago that
makes us behave differently when we
believe we're being watched by others
whatever the reasons behind its
Effectiveness the only way to know
whether body doubling works for you was
to try it out yourself tip number two is
to listen to noise in 2016 a study
involving 40 participants were split
into two groups 20 with ADHD and 20
without all participants took
intelligence tests that required
attention and brain power they took the
tests twice once while listening to
White Noise and once in Silence the ADHD
group was tested both with and without
their medication the results showed that
regardless of medication use individuals
with ADHD perform significantly better
in two tasks when exposed to White Noise
this Improvement was particularly
notable in tasks related to learning and
recalling words surprisingly when those
in the ADHD group took the tests on
their medication without white noise
there was no improvement this suggests
that the medication had no effect on
their performance highlighting that it
was the presence of white noise that
contributed to the enhanced scores a
more recent 2022 study by researchers in
Taiwan showed similar results the
researchers took over a 100 people half
with ADHD and tested their attention and
behavior with and without white noise
for those without issues focusing the
White Noise had little effect but for
the people with problems concentrating
using white noise improved their ability
to focus on their goals and they made
fewer mistakes they were also calmer and
less hyperactive so what's going on how
can more noise make us more productive
well many of us notice that we work best
not in total silence but when there's a
little background noise cars driving by
outside for example or a washing machine
weing away in another room it sounds
counterintuitive when concentrating we
might think that the best thing to do is
remove all possible distractions but
listening to White Noise can actually
improve our ability to stay on task
white noise is like a steady consistent
shushing or hissing it's a mixture of
all the different frequencies of sounds
that humans can hear played at the same
intensity you probably know what a TV or
radio set to a Channel with no station
sounds like the static sound is similar
to white noise here's what White Noise
sounds like
scientists believe that white noise
helps us Focus because it acts as a
consistent and predictable background
noise that stops us from being
distracted as much by random sounds in
the environment essentially White Noise
drowns out other noises so we don't
notice them as easily scientists also
think that it might work so well for
ADHD because white noise is suspected to
increased dopamine levels in the brain
which as we know are often lower in
people with ADHD if you don't have a
natural source of white noise in your
environment don't worry today it's easy
to find apps and playlists that do the
job just as well tip number three start
journaling you've probably heard all the
benefits of journaling from helping you
track goals to making you more organized
but it can also be an effective tool to
massively improve focus and productivity
people with ADHD often find that
completing even straightforward tasks
can be challenging the constant noise in
their minds and the struggle to filter
out distractions can be exhausting
however there's a transformative
solution at hand and it's been made
incredibly accessible through the day
one journaling app who are the sponsor
of today's video day one is designed to
revolutionize the journaling experience
it's more than just an app it's a tool
that empowers you to elevate your
productivity organize your thoughts
process your emotions and manage life's
responsibilities with EAS journaling
with day one can significantly impact
your life in several key ways first it
improves emotional processing people
with ADHD are more likely to experience
negative selft talk and find regulating
emotions difficult day one is a way to
express thoughts and feelings vent about
life's problems and identify emotional
patterns safely one study of 122
students found that those who journaled
about the emotions of a traumatic event
were better at seeing the positives in
it than those who only wrote about the
event factually secondly journaling can
enhance your Stress Management
capabilities people with ADHD generally
experience more stress when trying to
manage deadlines and balance demands as
a result they sometimes turn to
unhealthy coping mechanisms day one
helps get stressful and negative
thoughts out of your head and onto the
screen studies show that journaling can
be therapeutic relaxing anxiety and
helping you regain balance and with day
one's audio transcription feature and
our favorite feature too you can express
exactly how you feel and it will
expertly transcribe it all down for you
lastly research suggests that people
with ADHD sometimes struggle with
working memory day one helps by giving
you a written or drawn record of tasks
and Reflections to refer back to
stopping you from Forgetting important
information if you haven't journaled
before or want to get back into to it
try day one or go to day1 app.com
Improvement pill and use code
Improvement pill to unlock a limited
time offer of a twon free trial of Day
One Premium that's d y nea.com
Improvement pill and see why it's the
number one journaling app out there now
on to our next tip which is get enough
omega-3 when figuring out how to improve
attention and productivity we generally
look for the best hacks and techniques
which makes sense but research is
increasingly showing that there's a
tight link between focus and what we eat
for example the connection between
omega-3 and ADHD is well established a
comprehensive study from 2014 found that
people with ADHD have blood levels of
Omega-3 38% lower than in people without
it and research on almost 500 UK
residents found that those with lower
levels of Omega-3 were more angry and
aggressive and had more mood swings and
learning difficulties looking to learn
whether raising omega-3 would actually
improve focus once study tested 92
children and teenagers with ADHD to see
who was low in omega-3 and gave half
Omega-3 supplements and half a placebo
so no one knew which group they were
part of the trial lasted 12 weeks and
the participants were assessed using
various rigorous tests of attention
focus and impulsivity once at the
beginning of the study and again at the
end the researchers found that the
subjects low in omega-3 at the start
became more attentive and Vigilant and
performed better when tested at the end
of the experiment the results were so
strong that they were very unlikely to
be due to Chance in contrast anyone with
normal levels of Omega-3 at the start of
the trial saw no improvements we're
still learning about the link between
omega-3 and detention but given that
omega-3 is known to have a ton of
beneficial health effects from improving
heart health to raising mood including
more into your diet as long as it's not
too much is something there's no harm in
trying and finally tip number five
utilize the zarnik effect in the 19
1920s Dr zarnik a Soviet psychologist
was at a restaurant with friends when
she noticed that the waiters could
remember extremely long and complex
orders while the order was still active
and the restaurant goers hadn't gotten
their food but they would totally forget
everything as soon as the order was
completed even though they'd been able
to remember it just moments earlier
curious to know what was going on Zagar
conducted experiments to see whether
people were better at remembering
information when they were in the middle
of a task compared to when they had
finished it she would get participants
to solve a puzzle or learn some
information and stop half of them
partway through by making them do an
unrelated task like drawing or counting
backwards then she'd see whether those
who got interrupted were better at
remembering what they'd learned later on
zagar's studies found that subjects who
had to stop what they were doing before
it was done were better at remembering
what they had learned than those who
were allowed to complete them so why is
this her theory was that once we start a
task our brain develops something called
task specific tension task specific
specific tension improves our brain's
ability to access information memories
or thoughts when we need them making it
easier for us to succeed at what we're
doing and it only goes away when our
task is finished when we work on
something interesting and have to stop
suddenly the tension makes it harder to
concentrate fully on anything we want to
get back and finish people wanting to
improve their focus commonly use the
zaric effect in three ways one way is to
overcome procrastination by making it
start on your project even if you do
just a little to open the loop if it
doesn't matter how long you work on the
task or how much you do simply getting
started can significantly improve
motivation once you've begun building up
cognitive tension ideas about your task
will keep popping into your head and
you'll be eager to get back to it you
can also schedule breaks tactically so
that you're most engrossed in your task
when it's time to take some rest
research shows that students who stop
studying to take short breaks remember
the material much better than those who
don't take any this works best when you
do something completely unrelated to
your work like going for for a walk
finally try leaving your work on a
cliffhanger screenwriters and movie
Producers harness the zarnick effect by
using Cliffhangers to keep us coming
back but you can use it to your
advantage too instead of working until
the end of the day when you've done all
that needs doing leave your work at a
place that you'll be excited to come
back to keep your appetite wetted so
that you're excited and not anxious to
return the next day there's no reason
that struggling to focus should impact
your productivity if you're having
problems concentrating the tips and
tools we've exped here are guaranteed to
be helpful good luck trying them out for
yourself and besides that stay
tuned
